choices.text: 12 – 14 weeks
16 – 18 weeks
22 – 24 weeks
28 -30 weeks

questions.text: Fetal skin keratinizes by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 22 – 24 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal skin keratinizes by 22 – 25 weeks following which water transport across the fetal skin stops    
  • After keratinization of the fetal skin, transport of fluids across the skin is no longer a major contributor to amniotic fluid formation.

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. 12 – 14 weeks: At this stage, the fetus is still in the early stages of development. The epidermis, which is the outermost layer of skin, begins to form, but it's not fully developed yet. Keratinization has not started at this stage.

 

Option B. 16 – 18 weeks: By this time, the fetal skin has developed more layers. However, the process of keratinization is still not complete. The skin at this stage is relatively thin and transparent.

 

Option C. 22 – 24 weeks (Correct Answer): This is the stage where fetal skin keratinizes. Keratinization involves the maturation of keratinocytes (skin cells) as they move from the basal layer to the surface of the skin. By this stage, the fetus has a well-formed epidermis with multiple layers, and the skin starts to become more opaque and less translucent, largely due to the accumulation of keratin.

 

Option D. 28 – 30 weeks: The fetal skin is now more similar to postnatal skin, with a fully developed epidermal barrier. This development is crucial for the survival of the fetus outside the womb, as it plays a key role in protecting against infections and fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective: Fetal skin typically keratinizes by 22 – 24 weeks of gestation. This knowledge is crucial for understanding amniotic fluid dynamics and assessing fetal well-being during prenatal care, as keratinization marks an important developmental milestone in the fetus.

 

Ref: page no 225, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Hypo-osmolar
Hyper-osmolar
Same osmolality
Osmolality increases with gestational age

questions.text: In comparison to fetal plasma, the osmolality of amniotic fluid is
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypo-osmolar

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal urine/ amniotic fluid osmolality is about 260 mosm/l)
  • It is less than maternal and fetal plasma (280 mosm/l)
  • It is hypotonic
  • This hypotonicity accounts for significant intramembranous fluid transfer across fetal vessels on the placental surface (400ml/day)

 

Let's explore each option:

 

Option A. Hypo-osmolar (Correct Answer): This means that the concentration of solutes in amniotic fluid is lower than in fetal plasma. The osmolality of fetal urine and amniotic fluid is approximately 260 mosm/l, which is less than that of maternal and fetal plasma (typically around 280 mosm/l).

 

Option B. Hyper-osmolar: False. In a healthy pregnancy, amniotic fluid is less concentrated than fetal plasma.

 

Option C. Same Osmolality: False. Amniotic fluid is typically hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma.

 

Option D. Osmolality Increases with Gestational Age: While the composition of amniotic fluid can change throughout pregnancy, the osmolality of amniotic fluid generally remains hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma throughout gestation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Amniotic fluid is hypo-osmolar compared to fetal plasma (Option A), which plays a key role in fetal development and fluid balance across the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal urine
Intramembranous transfer
Respiratory tract secretions
Transfer across fetal skin

questions.text: At term, the major contributor of amniotic fluid is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

 

Explanation:

 

 

Let's examine each option for the major contributor of amniotic fluid at term:

 

Option A. Fetal Urine (Correct Answer): By the time of term pregnancy, fetal urine is the primary contributor to amniotic fluid. The fetal kidneys produce urine, which is then excreted into the amniotic sac.

 

Option B. Intramembranous Transfer: This refers to the movement of fluid across the membranes surrounding the fetus. While intramembranous transfer is a significant contributor to amniotic fluid volume earlier in pregnancy, its contribution is less at term compared to fetal urine.

 

Option C. Respiratory Tract Secretions: Fetal respiratory tract secretions do contribute to amniotic fluid, particularly as the fetus practices "breathing" movements in utero. However, this is not the major source of amniotic fluid at term.

 

Option D. Transfer Across Fetal Skin: Early in pregnancy, when the fetal skin is not fully keratinized, there can be significant fluid transfer across the skin. However, by term, the fetal skin has keratinized, significantly reducing its permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At term, the primary contributor to the volume of amniotic fluid is fetal urine. This reflects the maturity and functionality of the fetal kidneys, which play a crucial role in maintaining the appropriate amount and composition of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 42 weeks
38 weeks
36 weeks
32 weeks

questions.text: Amniotic fluid volume is maximum at:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Average volume versus gestational age

 

  • 20 weeks               -   400 ml
  • 28 weeks               -   800 - 1000 ml
  • 34 - 36 weeks       -   1000 – 1500 ml (peak)
  • 40 weeks               -   800ml (declines)  
  • After 40 weeks     -   Declines 150 ml/week
  • 42 weeks               -   400 ml

 

Educational Objective: Amniotic fluid volume peaks around 36 weeks of gestation. It is vital for fetal development and well-being, as deviations from this norm can indicate potential health issues.

 

Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 50 ml/ week
100 ml/week
150 ml/ week
200 ml/ week

questions.text: After 40 weeks, the amniotic fluid declines at the rate of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 150 ml/ week

 

Explanation

 

Average volume versus gestational age

 

  • 20 weeks             -      400 ml
  • 28 weeks             -      800 - 1000 ml
  • 34 – 36 weeks    -      1000 – 1500 ml (peak)
  • 40 weeks             -      800ml (declines)  
  • After 40 weeks   -      Declines 150 ml/week
  • 42 weeks             -      400 ml

 

Educational Objective: Recognizing that amniotic fluid typically decreases at a rate of approximately 150 ml per week after 40 weeks of gestation is crucial for evaluating the health and progress of a post-term pregnancy.

 

Ref: page no 225, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Quantitative
Qualitative
Semi-quantitative
Semi-qualitative

questions.text: Sonographic estimation of Amniotic fluid by Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Semi-quantitative

 

Explanation:

 

  • Correct quantitative measurement is done only in research settings using dye-dilution method,
  • In clinical settings - We do semiquantitative measurement by ultrasound. This is done by 2 methods:
    1. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)
    2. Single deepest vertical pocket measurement

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Quantitative: A quantitative measurement would imply a precise, numerical estimation of the amniotic fluid volume. While AFI does provide numerical values, it's not a direct measurement of the exact volume but rather an index based on ultrasound findings.

 

Option B. Qualitative: Qualitative measurements are descriptive and non-numerical.

 

Option C. Semi-quantitative (Correct Answer): AFI is considered semi-quantitative because it provides a numerical estimate based on the depth of fluid pockets in four quadrants of the uterus. It gives a numerical value but is not a direct or precise measurement of total fluid volume, hence 'semi-quantitative'.

 

Option D. Semi-qualitative: This term would imply a combination of numerical and descriptive assessment. Since AFI is primarily focused on providing a numerical index  rather than a descriptive analysis, this term is less accurate in describing it.

 

Educational Objective: Understanding that the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is a semi-quantitative method helps clinicians in assessing amniotic fluid volume, providing a balance between numerical estimation and clinical interpretation.

 

Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 5 – 15
5 – 25
8 – 15
8 – 25

questions.text: A 26-year primi undergoes an ultrasound at 37 weeks for fetal wellbeing. The report says the amniotic fluid index is normal. What is a normal AFI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 – 25

 

Explanation

 

Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)

 

  • The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman
  • The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – rt and left upper and lower quadrants
  • The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant.
  • So the unit of measurement is mm/ cm
  • Normal value: 5 – 25 (ACOG)

 

Educational Objective:

 

A normal Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) ranges from 5 to 25 cm. This range is important for assessing fetal wellbeing, as it indicates a sufficient volume of amniotic fluid for the fetus to move freely and develop properly.

 

Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 2- 8 mm
2 – 8 cm
5 – 10 mm
5 – 10 cm

questions.text: Single deepest pocket of amniotic fluid can be used to estimate the amniotic fluid volume. The normal value is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2 – 8 cm

 

Explanation:

 

Single Deepest Pocket

 

  • Or Maximal vertical pocket
  • The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman.
  • The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured.
  • Unit of measurement: cm/ mm
  • The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm
  • More useful in 2nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The single deepest pocket (SDP) method is a valuable tool for estimating amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy, with the normal range being 2 to 8 cm. This measurement helps in assessing the adequacy of amniotic fluid, which is crucial for the normal development and wellbeing of the fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Amniotic fluid index
Deepest vertical pocket of liquor
BPD and HC
Cervical length

questions.text: The image below shows measurement of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid index

 

Explanation:

 

Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)

 

The ultrasound transducer is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman. The uterus is divided into 4 equal quadrants – right and left upper and lower quadrants

 

The AFI is the sum of the single deepest pocket from each quadrant.

 

So the unit of measurement is mm/ cm

 

Normal value: 5 – 25 (ACOG)

 

 Let us look at the other options:

 

Option B. Deepest Vertical Pocket (DVP) of Liquor: The DVP method measures the single deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid without fetal parts or umbilical cord. This measurement is taken as a single deepest unobstructed vertical length. In the image, if only one pocket is being measured for its vertical length, it could represent the DVP.

 

Option C. BPD and HC (Biparietal Diameter and Head Circumference): These are measurements of fetal head size. BPD is the diameter between the two sides of the head, and HC is the circumference around the head. These measurements are not related to amniotic fluid and are typically not assessed in the same ultrasound view that is used for AFI or DVP.

 

Option D. Cervical Length: This measures the length of the cervix, usually to assess the risk of preterm labor. This is not what is shown in the image, as cervical length measurements are taken by transvaginal ultrasound and focus solely on the cervix, not the amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ultrasound assessment of a pregnant woman, the Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is calculated by summing the depths of the largest pockets of amniotic fluid in four quadrants of the uterus. It is a crucial parameter for assessing the well-being of the fetus, as both low and high volumes of amniotic fluid can have clinical implications.

 

Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Baarter Syndrome
Ebstein anomaly
Fetal myotonic dystrophy
Posterior urethral valve

questions.text: All are causes of polyhydramnios except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior urethral valve

Explanation:

 

Etiology of Polyhydramnios:

 

  1. Idiopathic: Most Common (66%)
  2. Fetal Anomalies
    • Causing impaired swallowing
      • CNS – Anencephaly, Hydranencephaly, Holoprosencephaly
      • Craniofacial – Cleft palate, micrognathia
    • Causing Obstruction to Swallowing:
      • Cystic hygroma
      • Congenital high airway obstruction sequence (CHAOS)
    • GI Obstruction
      • Esophageal atresia
      • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
      • Duodenal atresia
    • Neurological
      • Myotonic dystrophy
    • High output cardiac failure
      • Ebstein’s anomaly (Seen in Lithium intake)
      • Tetralogy of Fallot
      • Cardiomyopathy
    • Metabolic:
      • Baarter Syndrome
  3. Placental
    • Chorioangioma
    • Circumvallate placenta
  4. Along with fetal hydrops
    • Immune hydrops (Rh isoimmunization)
    • Non immune hydrops e.g. associated with CMV, toxoplasmosis, syphilis and parvovirus)
  5. Diabetes mellitus: Fetal hyperglycemia causes fetal osmotic diuresis
  6. Multifetal gestation: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Bartter Syndrome: This is a group of rare inherited disorders that affect the kidneys and can result in an imbalance of electrolytes, among other issues. While it's not a direct and common cause of polyhydramnios, any severe imbalance in the fetal environment that affects urine production or fluid balance could potentially contribute to polyhydramnios.

 

Option B. Ebstein Anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is malformed and positioned lower than normal in the right ventricle. It can lead to heart failure and hydrops in the fetus, which can cause polyhydramnios due to an increase in fetal plasma volume and urine production.

 

Option C. Fetal Myotonic Dystrophy: This is a form of muscular dystrophy that can present in the fetus or at birth. Affected infants may have a poor swallowing reflex and decreased fetal movements, leading to polyhydramnios because the fetus is unable to swallow and absorb the amniotic fluid adequately.

 

Option D. Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV): This is an obstructive congenital anomaly found in males, where there is a blockage in the urethra caused by excess tissue growth. This condition typically causes oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) rather than polyhydramnios, due to the obstruction of urinary flow out of the bladder, leading to less fluid being contributed to the amniotic sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etiology of Polyhydramnios:

 

  1. Idiopathic: Most Common (66%)
  2. Fetal Anomalies
    • Causing impaired swallowing
      • CNS – Anencephaly, Hydranencephaly, Holoprosencephaly
      • Craniofacial – Cleft palate, micrognathia
    • Causing Obstruction to Swallowing:
      • Cystic hygroma
      • Congenital high airway obstruction sequence (CHAOS)
    • GI Obstruction
      • Esophageal atresia
      • Tracheo-esophageal fistula
      • Duodenal atresia
    • Neurological
      • Myotonic dystrophy
    • High output cardiac failure
      • Ebstein’s anomaly (Seen in Lithium intake)
      • Tetralogy of Fallot
      • Cardiomyopathy
    • Metabolic:
      • Baarter Syndrome
  3. Placental
    • Chorioangioma
    • Circumvallate placenta
  4. Along with fetal hydrops
    • Immune hydrops (Rh isoimmunization)
    • Non immune hydrops e.g. associated with CMV, toxoplasmosis, syphilis and parvovirus)
  5. Diabetes mellitus: Fetal hyperglycemia causes fetal osmotic diuresis
  6. Multifetal gestation: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Ref: page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Associated cardiac anomalies
Double bubble sign
Macrosomia
Polyhydramnios

questions.text: A 20-year primigravida is diagnosed to have duodenal atresia on her routine level 2 scan done at 20 weeks. Which of the following would NOT have been seen on the ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macrosomia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%)
  • On ultrasound –
    • Double bubble sign
    • Polyhydramnios

 

 

Double bubble sign


Duodenal atresia is a congenital defect in which there is a closure or absence of a portion of the lumen of the duodenum. It can be diagnosed prenatally during a routine level 2 scan at around 20 weeks of gestation. Let's look at each option:

 

Option A. Associated Cardiac Anomalies: Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with other anomalies, including cardiac anomalies. About 30% of infants with duodenal atresia also have congenital heart disease.

 

Option B. Double Bubble Sign: This sign refers to two distinct fluid-filled areas seen on ultrasound, representing the stomach and the proximal duodenum. It is a classic sign of duodenal atresia as the duodenum is distended due to the obstruction.

 

Option C. Macrosomia: This term refers to a newborn who is significantly larger than average, often defined as a birth weight of more than 4,000 to 4,500 grams. Macrosomia would not be a finding in the case of duodenal atresia, especially at 20 weeks, since it generally refers to the condition of a newborn at birth. Duodenal atresia may cause growth issues due to nutrient malabsorption, but it is not associated with an increased fetal size in utero.

 

Option D. Polyhydramnios: Since the fetus is unable to properly process and absorb amniotic fluid due to the atresia, this can lead to an accumulation of fluid in the amniotic sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On a prenatal ultrasound, the "double bubble" sign is indicative of duodenal atresia, and associated cardiac anomalies may also be present. Polyhydramnios can occur due to the fetus's inability to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid properly. Macrosomia, which describes a newborn with a significantly larger than average birth weight, is not related to duodenal atresia and would not be seen on the ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation

 

Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Prelabor rupture of membranes
Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidneys
Prematurity
Posterior urethral valve

questions.text: A 30-yearG2P1 is found to have oligohydramnios at 28 weeks. All are causes of oligohydramnios except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prematurity

 

Explanation

 

Etiology of Oligohydramnios

 

  • Decreased urine production
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency – preeclampsia, FGR
    • Placental maturity (post term)
    • Medication:
      • ACE-I
      • ARB
      • NSAIDs
    • Fetal renal anomalies:
      • B/l renal agenesis
      • B/l multicystic dysplastic kidneys
      • Infantile form of Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
  • Obstruction to the Renal outflow tract
    • Posterior urethral valve (keyhole sign)
    • Urethral atresia/ stenosis
    • Megacystis microcolon intestinal hypoperistalsis syndrome
    • Sirenomelia
  • Loss of Amniotic fluid
    • PPROM
  • Others
    • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome
  • Idiopathic

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Prelabor Rupture of Membranes (PROM): PROM refers to the breaking of the amniotic sac and leakage of amniotic fluid before the onset of labor. This can lead to a significant decrease in the amount of amniotic fluid, causing oligohydramnios. This condition is more common in the later stages of pregnancy but can occur at any time after the mid-second trimester.

 

Option B. Bilateral Multicystic Dysplastic Kidneys: This is a condition where the kidneys develop cysts and are nonfunctional from birth. Since the kidneys are responsible for producing urine, which contributes significantly to amniotic fluid, their dysfunction can lead to reduced fluid production and oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. Prematurity (Correct Answer): Prematurity, per se, is not a direct cause of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is more typically associated with specific fetal or maternal conditions rather than the gestational age of the fetus. Prematurity may be a consequence of other complications in pregnancy but is not a cause of oligohydramnios.

 

Option D. Posterior Urethral Valve: This condition is an obstruction of the male urethra. It can lead to a decrease in the amount of urine reaching the amniotic sac, which in turn can result in oligohydramnios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligohydramnios, a condition marked by insufficient amniotic fluid, can be caused by factors such as the prelabor rupture of membranes, renal abnormalities like bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidneys, and obstructive uropathies like posterior urethral valve. Prematurity itself is not a cause of oligohydramnios; rather, it may be a result of complications including oligohydramnios during pregnancy. Early detection and management of oligohydramnios are crucial for optimizing fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Cystic hygroma
Duodenal atresia
Posterior urethral valve
Renal agenesis

questions.text: A 36-yearprimigravida presented for an anomaly scan at 20 weeks. The following image was noted on the ultrasound along with polyhydramnios. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenal atresia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Duodenal atresia is associated with other anomalies (Cardiac, renal & vertebral in 10%)
  • On ultrasound –
    • Double bubble sign (as seen in the image in the question)
    • Polyhydramnios
  • Posterior urethral valve and renal agenesis will have Oligohydrmanios
  • Cystic hygroma will appear as a septated swelling:

 

Let us look at each option :

 

Option A. Cystic Hygroma: This is a fluid-filled sac that results from a blockage in the lymphatic system. It typically appears as a large, cystic mass in the neck region of the fetus. While cystic hygroma can be associated with other abnormalities, it does not directly cause polyhydramnios .

 

Option B. Duodenal Atresia (Correct Answer): This is characterized by a blockage in the duodenum, which is part of the small intestine. On an ultrasound, duodenal atresia is suggested by the "double bubble" sign – two distinct fluid-filled areas seen in the fetal abdomen, representing the stomach and the proximal duodenum. Polyhydramnios is often present because the fetus cannot swallow and absorb amniotic fluid normally due to the intestinal obstruction.

 

Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve: This condition, which occurs only in males, is characterized by a blockage in the urethra due to abnormal tissue growth. The key ultrasound finding is typically a dilated bladder and, in some cases, hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidneys). This condition is more likely to lead to oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) rather than polyhydramnios.

 

Option D. Renal Agenesis: This is the absence of one or both kidneys. When both kidneys are absent (bilateral renal agenesis), there is usually oligohydramnios because the fetus cannot produce urine to contribute to the amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of duodenal atresia is suggested by the presence of a "double bubble" sign on ultrasound. This finding, combined with polyhydramnios, is indicative of an obstruction in the fetal gastrointestinal tract, specifically at the duodenum, leading to an accumulation of amniotic fluid.

 

Ref: Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Renal agenesis
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Posterior urethral valve
Dysplastic kidneys

questions.text: Keyhole sign on ultrasound is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior urethral valve

 

Explanation:

 

  • Posterior urethral valve causes obstruction to the outflow of urine in male fetus
  • On ultrasound
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Distended bladder seen giving the appearance of keyhole   

 

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. Renal Agenesis: This is the absence of one or both kidneys at birth.There would be an absence of the kidney(s) and possibly associated findings related to the lack of urine production.

 

Option B. Ureteropelvic Junction Obstruction: This condition involves a blockage in the area where the ureter joins the kidney, impeding the flow of urine into the bladder. Ultrasound findings might include hydronephrosis.

 

Option D. Dysplastic Kidneys: Renal dysplasia involves the malformation of the kidneys during fetal development. The ultrasound might show enlarged kidneys with cysts and other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound is indicative of posterior urethral valve obstruction. This sign reflects the dilation of the posterior urethra and the bladder caused by the obstruction and is an important diagnostic clue for this condition. Detecting PUV is critical because it can lead to significant morbidity if not addressed promptly after birth

 

Ref : Page 230, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Bilateral polycystic kidney disease
Renal agenesis
Early PPROM
Tracheoesophageal fistula

questions.text: Potter's sequence is seen in all the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheoesophageal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

Potter's sequence is the effect chronic oligohydramnios has on the fetus. It includes

 

  1. Growth restriction
  2. Pulmonary hypoplasia
  3. Potter facies (low set ears, flattened nose and micrognathia)
  4. Limb contractures and club foot.

 

  • Causes of early onset oligohydramnios like bilateral fetal renal anomalies or very preterm rupture of membranes can cause Potters sequence.
  • Tracheo-esophageal fistula causes polyhydramnios

 

Let's look at  each option :

 

Option A. Bilateral Polycystic Kidney Disease: This condition can cause the kidneys to be nonfunctional due to the replacement of normal kidney tissue with multiple cysts. It can result in oligohydramnios and lead to the development of Potter's sequence .

 

Option B. Renal Agenesis: This refers to the congenital absence of one or both kidneys. Bilateral renal agenesis is directly associated with Potter's sequence because without kidneys, the fetus cannot produce urine, leading to a significant reduction in amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Early Preterm Premature Rupture of Membranes (PPROM): PPROM can lead to the leakage of amniotic fluid long before the pregnancy has reached term, which can result in prolonged oligohydramnios. This can cause the physical deformities characteristic of Potter's sequence due to the lack of cushioning fluid around the fetus.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: This is a congenital anomaly where there is an abnormal connection (fistula) between the trachea and the esophagus. While this condition can result in polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid, it does not cause oligohydramnios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potter's sequence is associated with conditions that lead to oligohydramnios, such as bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral polycystic kidney disease, and situations causing chronic leakage of amniotic fluid like early PPROM. It is characterized by a set of physical deformities that arise due to the lack of amniotic fluid and the resulting compression of the developing fetus.

 

Ref: page no 231, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 7.2
6.8
7.8
6.2

questions.text: The pH of the amniotic fluid is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 7.2

 

Explanation

 

The pH of the amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline (7.2)

 

Other features of amniotic fluid:

 

  • Color: straw colored / colorless
  • 1st half of pregnancy: composition is identical to a transudate of plasma; altered later once the main component becomes fetal urine.
  • Faintly alkaline
  • Low specific gravity (1.010)
  • Hypotonic at term; osmolarity; 250mOsm /I at term (decreases with increasing age)
  • Color
  • Contains lanugo, exfoliated squamous epithelial, vernix caseosa etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal pH of amniotic fluid is slightly alkaline, usually around 7.2. Amniotic fluid pH is a vital sign of the fetal environment, and deviations from the normal range can indicate potential clinical concerns that may necessitate further investigation and intervention.

 

Ref: page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Gestational age > 32 weeks
Polyhydramnios due to anencephaly
Muscular dystrophy in the fetus
Non-immune hydrops

questions.text: A 25-year primi is diagnosed to have polyhydramnios. She complains of severe discomfort due to the over distended abdomen. You decide to start indomethacin to reduce the liquor. Which of the following is a contra indication for using this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational age > 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Indomethacin and sulindac are used in the treatment of severe polyhydramnios
  • However, if given after 32 weeks: there is risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and hence are contra-indicated after 32 weeks

 

Premature closure can lead to pulmonary hypertension and heart failure in the fetus.

 

Let's look at the other options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios due to anencephaly: Polyhydramnios can occur in this setting because the fetus cannot swallow amniotic fluid normally, leading to its accumulation. While indomethacin may be used to reduce fluid volume, it doesn't address the underlying condition, which is incompatible with life outside the womb.

 

Option C. Muscular dystrophy in the fetus: Fetal muscular dystrophy may be associated with polyhydramnios due to decreased fetal swallowing and movement. Indomethacin would not be a contraindication unless the gestational age is beyond 32 weeks or other specific risks are identified.

 

Option D. Non-immune hydrops: This is a condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments. While indomethacin may reduce the amniotic fluid component, it's not the treatment for the underlying causes of non-immune hydrops. Indomethacin use is not strictly contraindicated by the presence of hydrops itself .

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indomethacin is contraindicated for use in reducing amniotic fluid volume in the context of polyhydramnios when the gestational age is greater than 32 weeks due to the increased risk of adverse fetal effects, such as premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Ref: Page no 229, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal demise
Fetal distress
Rh isoimmunization
Post maturity

questions.text: A 30-year G3 is in labor at 37 weeks. At 5cm cervical dilatation, an amniotomy is done. Golden color of amniotic fluid is seen. What could be a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rh isoimmunization

 

Explanation

 

Color of liquor –

 

  • In early pregnancy: It is colorless
  • Straw colored: Near term
  • Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia
  • Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity
  • Red: Abruption
  • Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise

 

Now, let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Fetal Demise: Amniotic fluid may become discolored due to the breakdown of fetal red blood cells and the release of bile pigment. The fluid is more likely to appear dark or brownish, often referred to as "port-wine" colored due to hemolysis.

 

Option B. Fetal Distress: Fetal distress can lead to the passage of meconium into the amniotic fluid, which typically gives the fluid a greenish tint.

 

Option C. Rh Isoimmunization: This occurs when an Rh-negative mother becomes sensitized to Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. The immune response leads to hemolysis of the fetal red blood cells, and the release of bilirubin, which can give the amniotic fluid a yellow or golden color. This condition is also known as hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).

 

Option D. Post Maturity: Post maturity refers to a pregnancy that extends beyond 42 weeks. Post maturity is more commonly associated with oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid volume) and the presence of meconium, which would make the fluid greenish if the fetus has passed stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Color of liquor –

 

  • In early pregnancy: It is colorless
  • Straw colored: Near term
  • Deep yellow/ golden color: Fetal anemia
    • Green (meconium stained): fetal distress or post-maturity
    • Red: Abruption
    • Dark colored/ tobacco like: Fetal demise

 

Ref: Page no 226, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Oligohydramnios
Multiple pregnancy
Fibroid uterus
Polyhydramnios

questions.text: A 24-yearlady presents to the OPD at 32 weeks gestation. On examination the uterus is 36 weeks in height and the fetal parts are not easily palpable. The FHR is heard distant and faint. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Polyhydramnios

 

Explanation:

 

Important Clinical Features in Polyhydramnios

 

  • Symptoms: Discomfort mainly
  • Signs:
    • Pedal edema
    • P/A
  • Inspection: Overdistension, umbilicus everted, stretched shiny skin
  • Palpation:
    • Fetal parts not felt easily
    • Ballotability easy to elicit
    • Fluid thrill
  • Auscultation: FHR faint

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. Oligohydramnios: This condition is characterized by a lower-than-normal amount of amniotic fluid. It would typically present with a smaller uterine size relative to gestational age, not larger. Fetal parts may be more easily palpable due to the decreased cushioning from the amniotic fluid, and the FHR would not necessarily be distant or faint.

 

Option B. Multiple Pregnancy: A twin or multiple pregnancy can cause an enlarged uterus. However, in such cases, fetal parts are usually more readily palpable, and the FHRs would be more distinct and possibly multiple.

 

Option C. Fibroid Uterus: Fibroids are benign tumors of the uterus that can distort the uterine shape and size. While a fibroid uterus can cause an enlarged uterus, it typically wouldn't make the FHR distant or faint. Additionally, fibroids do not directly affect the amniotic fluid volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important Clinical Features in Polyhydramnios

 

  • Symptoms: Discomfort mainly
  • Signs:
    • Pedal edema
    • P/A
      • Inspection: Overdistension, umbilicus everted, stretched shiny skin
      • Palpation:
    • Fetal parts not felt easily
    • Ballotability easy to elicit
    • Fluid thrill
  • Auscultation: FHR faint

 

Ref: page no 228, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
